Around 400 members of our community in Colehill gathered for the 2022 Remembrance Day parade and service at Colehill War Memorial, including representatives from the Parish Council, Army, Royal Air Force, Police, Fire Brigade, Scouts, Guides and St Michael’s School.
The Vice Chair of the Parish Council, Cllr Leslie Gibson, read out the names of Colehill residents who fell in the two World Wars and retired military bandsman Andy Urquhart, played the Last Post followed by the two minutes silence.
This year’s event had a special poignancy with the sad loss of HM The Queen and a war now underway in Europe,
Lest we forget.

“Susan has lived in Colehill since 2009. Between 2011 and 2020 she was a Colehill Parish Councillor, and was Chair of the Parish Council between 2015-17. She is very happy to be back on the Parish Council once again.
She is now retired from work and currently enjoys volunteering for several local charities and for the NHS. In her spare time she enjoys reading, gardening and researching her family tree, and most days can be seen out and about walking locally with her partner and their Border Terrier. ”
Susan lives and represents residents in the Colehill Parish Ward although is of course keen to hear from all and any residents in any part of Colehill.
| Email Address | scowsill@colehill.gov.uk |

Summary
Free Children's Community Event at Oliver's Park
Friday 27th August 10am to 1pm – Oliver’s Park, Cutlers Place, Colehill
10am – 11am A circus workshop starts the entertainment where both children and adults can have a go at juggling, plate spinning, diablo, ribbon twirling and more!
11:20am – 12pm It’s time for the Jamie Jigsaw magic and juggling show, packed with funny magic, hilarious juggling, lots of silliness and audience participation.
12:15pm – 1pm Balloon modelling – the children can each take home a balloon including balloon dogs, swords, laser guns, ladybirds, flowers and teddy bears, almost anything they can imagine!
Sweet stall and Ice cream van will be available.
You must not attend if showing any symptoms or have tested positive for Covid-19. Please note there will no parking in the Oliver’s Park car park and no loo’s so go before you come!

Library pages
CCL About Us Supporters Community News
Activities & Events Books Services Event Reports
Colehill Community Library offers full access to the Dorset Library service plus MORE!
Library Service Charges are available on the Dorset Council Site
JUNE 2020 – Download Digital Newspapers for free with your library card! See last section below.
-
Join the Dorset Library Service (now a member of LibrariesWest) – its FREE
Fill in a membership form at the Library or join online
Remember to bring proof of address when presenting your application form at the library
You will receive a Dorset Library membership card which gives you access to all of the LibrariesWest service.
-
Browse and borrow from the constantly changing selection of fiction and non-fiction books.
There is a very good selection of large print books and our children’s area is well used by our younger readers delving into the book boxes, researching their homework and browsing for the latest novels.
They also enjoy regular puzzles and colouring, often while cuddling one or more of our collection of soft toys.
Babies and push chairs are very welcome.
There is also a regularly updated selection of books for teens (on your right as you enter the library).
-
Request books, audio visual items or information
Our volunteers are always pleased to help you find books and request titles.
You will be notified as soon as your request is available for collection at Colehill.
We are also happy to help in searching for information both in books and on the Internet.
CDs and DVDs may be requested and collected from Colehill.
-
Can’t visit the Library
Ask about our Good Neighbour scheme – we are willing to hold books for a nominated person to collect on your behalf or to arrange delivery and collection of requested items.
Alternatively we can help you to join the Housebound Readers scheme which provides for a delivery service by the Royal Voluntary Service.
-
Internet Access and Computer use
The Library has two public access computers which may be used for up to 2 hours any day for free.
Printing – 10p a sheet for black/white and 50p for colour
There is free Wi-Fi in the Library.
-
Jig Saw Library
Borrow from a selection of over 100 puzzles (increasing all the time). Just make your selection from our colour catalogue in the lobby and ask a volunteer to bring your choice to you. There is no charge and no time limit.
-
Local Information
There is a selection of local maps and leaflets and flyers on local activities and organisations.
There is also a small but interesting collection on the history of the area which we hope to expand. All contributions are welcome.
-
Photocopying and Laminating
The Library has a colour photocopier and a laminator. Both can deal with up to A3 sizes.
Charges:
Copying A4 Black/white 10p, A4 Colour 30p
Copying A3 Black/white 20p, A3 Colour 60p
Laminating: A5 10p, A4 20p, A3 25p
-
Reading Groups
Ask for more information about help with your Reading Groups.
~~~
Download Digital Newspapers for free with your library card!
Digital Newspapers are available to library members in BCP (Bournemouth, Christchurch & Poole) and Dorset.
- Access the full text of 1000+ daily, weekly and monthly newspapers from over 100 countries (and in 60 languages), including 166 local, regional and national UK titles
- Available titles include – Daily Mail, Daily Mirror, Daily Telegraph, Guardian, Independent, Observer, Western Daily Press and hundreds more!
- Unlimited access for all library members in BCP (Bournemouth, Christchurch & Poole), Dorset
- Newspapers can be streamed online via a tablet, smart phone (app available for iOS, Android & Kindle Fire) or web browser. Titles can be read in either Page View (full text of the paper as it would appear in the print version) or Text View (article based)
- Titles are always available on the day of publication, including supplements
- Up to 3 month’s of back issues available for most titles
- Use the search function to find articles – search by keyword(s) with options to refine your search by date, country, language, specific publication etc
- Option to change the interface language from English to a number of other languages
- Option to have the paper read out loud
For library members in BCP or Dorset
If you already use RB Digital to access digital magazines or comics you can now access digital newspapers on the same platform.
If you use the RB Digital app
1. Log out of the app
2. Login again with your username and select your local authority name from the list. (Don’t select Libraries West as this will take you the platform without newspapers).
3. Type in your password
4. Tap on the icon in the top left corner of the home screen and select Newspapers
5. Tap on Checkout to access the Digital Newspapers service
6. Start browsing the collection and enjoy!
If you access RB Digital using a web browser
1. Go to the relevant website for your local library service –
Poole (including Christchurch & Highcliffe)
2. Sign in with your username and password
3. Scroll down the screen and you should see Newspapers appear
4. Click on the Press Reader icon and then ‘Access’ to checkout the newspaper collection
5. Start browsing the collection and enjoy!
If you don’t already have an RB Digital account you will need to create one:
Using a smartphone or tablet
1. Download the free RB Digital app from your app store (available for iO, Android & Kindle Fire)
2. Create an account with your library membership number by tapping on ‘Register Now’ and following the on-screen instructions. When it asks you to choose the library select BCP or Dorset, as relevant.
3. Once you have registered, scroll down to Newspapers and tap on ‘Access’. This will provide access to the entire collection of available newspapers.
4. Start browsing the collection and enjoy!
Using a web browser
1. Create a free RB Digital account with your library membership number by clicking on the relevant link below and then on ‘Register’ to complete your personal details.
Library members in Bournemouth
Library members in Christchurch & Poole
2. Once you have signed in, scroll down the page and you should see Newspapers.
3. Click on the Press Reader icon and then on ‘Access’. This will provide access to the entire collection of available newspapers.
4. Start browsing the collection and enjoy!
Help and advice is available on the website and app, but if you are stuck email RB Digital
We also offer a range of other digital newspaper resources which vary by local authority and can be accessed from the links below

Dorset’s councils are considering reducing the number of councils in the county from nine to two from 2019 in order to protect services and reduce costs as their funding continues to decline.
We’re working together to listen to what residents, businesses and others think about the proposals – we want to hear your views before any decisions are made.
The public consultation on the proposals for change runs until 25 October 2016 – you can fill out the consultation questionnaire online now.
Alternatively, before having your say, you can find out about the options, the background, read FAQs, or visit a roadshow we’re holding across Bournemouth, Dorset and Poole to talk to local people about the consultation.
It’s all here: http://reshapingyourcouncils.uk
(Note: this applies to District & County Councils; Parish and Town Councils will continue and may have enhanced roles.)

Dorset Group
The Hardy Plant Society has around 7,000 members in the UK and abroad ~ it exists to stimulate interest in growing hardy herbaceous plants. The Dorset Group was formed in 1998.
Please see the dorsethps.org.uk, for full details.
Group Tel: 07468 853009,
Email: dorsethps@gmail.com.

Club meetings are monthly at 7.30pm on the 3rd Monday at Colehill Village Hall.
Come and enjoy demonstrations followed by flower raffle and refreshments.
We sometimes have workshops, where, if you wish, you can ‘have a go’ or just come and watch.
We also have outings and talks. Please come along – you’ll be very welcome.
Enquiries:
Anne Clark; Tel: 01202 575951
Janet Lee, Tel: 01202 610902

Summary
New Councillor Drop in Morning
Colehill Parish Council are holding an information morning for residents interested in becoming a Councillor at the upcoming election on 2nd May 2024 in the Betty Webster Committee Room at Colehill Village Hall. There will be sitting Councillors and the Clerk on hand to discuss the role and answer any of your questions as well as copies of the application form and on-hand help with completing these. See the poster below for more details.

Richard has lived in Colehill for 18 years and was co-opted to the Council in December 2024. He recently retired from his professional activities in system design in the electricity and gas industries after a long and varied career spanning operational research, management consultancy, merchant banking, mining industry finance, privatisation of UK industry and information technology.
He is keen to get involved in how the local Council can best serve local residents, in cooperation with neighbouring Councils and with Dorset Council. His interests include music, yoga, boating, and his Austin 7, but all subject to involvement with the activities and aspirations of his children and grandchildren.
Richard is happy to hear from any residents in any part of Colehill.

Notice of Vacancy in Office of Councillor
NOTICE IS HEREBY GIVEN
Pursuant to Section 87(2) of the Local Government Act 1972, that Michael Gibbs
has ceased to be a Member of the Parish Council, and that a
vacancy now exists in the office of Councillor for the Parish Council.
If within 14 days after the date of this notice (i.e. no later than 11 November
2024) a request for an election to fill the vacancy is made to the Returning
Officer, Electoral Services, Dorset Council, County Hall, Dorchester, Dorset,
DT1 1XJ or by email to elections@dorsetcouncil.gov.uk by TEN electors who
are registered in the Parish Ward where the vacancy has arisen, an election
will be held to fill the vacancy, otherwise the vacancy will be filled by co-option.
If an election is called, it will take place not later than 17 January 2025.
Dated 22 October 2024
Zoe Caddy
Clerk to Colehill Parish Council

New donation form now available – see ‘Support Us’ below.
‘The Barbara Gooch Memorial Garden’ Appeal
We are delighted to report that the Appeal raised over £1,200. Thank you to everyone who contributed. ‘The Barbara Gooch Memorial Garden’ is located at the side of the library. Barbara was in charge of gardening volunteers and it was her dream to install a garden in this location, with plants and shrubs appropriate to the location. She and a plant expert planned the garden, but sadly, Barbara passed away before her dream could be realised.
Support Us
Our Community Library is reliant on support from the community. Here are a few ways you can help:
- Make a one-off or regular donation via the CCL Donation Form (pdf).
- Come along to a fundraising event – see our Activities & Events page
- Make a Supporter’s Subscription, via the Supporter’s Subscription form
- Help run the library and volunteer! Volunteer application form pdf (or Volunteer application form doc if you wish to fill it in using Office)
It is by volunteer effort and fund raising that we keep this community hub going. We welcome your support via small subscriptions and encourage you to join in the fundraising events. Please note that as Colehill Community Library is a registered charity we can claim Gift Aid, so it will be appreciated if you can complete the declaration where appropriate. The regular Newsletter will be sent to you by email or will be available in the library for you to collect. Also it can be downloaded from the News page.
Volunteering
We are run entirely by a substantial and committed team of volunteers who support the Library in a variety of ways. Approximately 40 volunteers man the library during opening hours over the course of a fortnight. Others are involved with general maintenance and cleaning of the building, gardening and ground maintenance, fund raising, running monthly activities and managing the Jigsaw Library.
Reg. Charity No. 1151552. Registered as a Company Limited by Guarantee 08124849.

We’ve planted 7 ornamental trees in Oliver’s Park field for HM The Queen’s Green Canopy.

January 2022
We’ve planted 7 ornamental trees in Oliver’s Park field for HM The Queen’s Green Canopy.
See our Oliver’s Park page for more details and to provide us with feedback on other improvements you’d like to see.

Overview
- We are refurbishing the children’s playground at Oliver’s Park in Colehill, focusing on the needs of younger children (age 1 to 8).
- We issued an invitation for companies to tender, asking them to submit proposals for the best play area they can provide at two alternative budget points of £50,000 and £70,000.
- We received 11 alternative options, and obtained feedback on these from our residents as well as local ‘in school’ consultations with children up to aged 9 to help us reach a decision.
Key Requirements
The main requirements we specified were:
- We would like to replace the infant wooden multi-play unit, which has deteriorated significantly, with a mix of equipment covering the full 1 to 8 age range.
- We would like new swings to replace the existing set which are deteriorating, ideally with a toddler seat, two junior seats and a basket swing.
- The junior multi-play unit, small boulders, see-saw and speaker tubes should be retained.
- All equipment and installation must be fully compliant to the playground standards BS EN 1176.
- Old equipment should be removed and safely disposed of, recycling where practical.
- We would prefer timber or other naturalistic materials that fit with the surroundings.
- The equipment should be robust, long-lasting and as vandal-proof as possible.
- A reasonable proportion of the equipment should be accessible by disabled children.
Public Consultation
- The public consultation via this website closed on 19th November 2023.
- We will also be seeking feedback directly from children via local schools and nurseries.
Options
You can see the 11 options by clicking on the images below. This view lets you click through each of the images in turn..
If you’d like to look at any of the options in more detail, you can click on the individual images shown below. and zoom in..
Use the back button on your browser to return to this page after viewing each image.

Outcome
- The public consultation via this website closed on 19th November 2023.
- We received a total of 36 responses containing both ‘votes’ for the artworks produced as well as other comments including a clear message that users did not want the overall swing capacity reduced and that the green slide on the larger piece of play equipment is not as user friendly as it could be.
- The ‘face to face’ consultations carried out by school staff with children attending local schools and nurseries voted designs E & D as their two favourites.
- As a result, following examination of the tenders, design and public opinion, Councillors at their meeting on 5th December resolved to have design D installed at the beginning of 2024 and having taken onboard feedback from respondents, have also decided to have the green slide replaced with a design that is straight, less steep and hopefully less static as it’s being formulated from a new ‘anti-static’ product. The replacement work for this equipment has an anticipated start date of 12th February.

This is on the post adjacent to the OneStop shop in Dales Drive – but pointing back up the hill into the village.
This is the first time we have tried this in that direction – there are obvious compromises with it recording traffic on the opposite side of the road, but there are reports of vehicles coming round that bend at Willow Drive rather too quickly and potentially ending up on the wrong side of the white lines.
It is interesting to note the number of vehicle movements. We generally suggest that there are just under 20,000 vehicle movements per week passing along Middlehill Road – and this is nearly 20% higher. Are they all coming from the Bridleway estate or up Hayes Lane (from Cutlers Place etc) and then out?

This morning, 15th August 2020, on the 75th anniversary of VJ Day (Victory over Japan), a few members of our community gathered in the drizzle at the War Memorial in Colehill. The Chairman of the Parish Council, Cllr Emma Urquhart, read a short statement, her husband, retired military bandsman Andy Urquhart, played the Last Post and a minute’s silence was held. The Reveille was played and Chris Brown, who serves as Crier to both Colehill and Wimborne, cried the remembrance of the end of hostilities 75 years ago.
For the annual Remembrance Day Ceremony in November the roads are closed temporarily and the traffic is still, however this was not possible today and the traffic noise on the video is quite intrusive.
#Colehill, #VJDay, #CryforPeace

August 2020

Ann was co-opted onto the council in 2022 – seeing it as an opportunity to be an active member of the community, promoting the interests of the residents of Colehill. She is a retired G.P. having practised as senior partner in a G.P. practice in Northborne/Kinson for 34 years. Ann and her husband moved to Colehill in1996; they have two grown up children, who were educated locally, and four grandchildren.
Since retirement Ann’s interests include dog walking and cycling in the countryside, music, history and the Arts.
Ann lives and represents residents in the Colehill Parish Ward although is of course keen to hear from all and any residents in any part of Colehill.

“Cherubs” Parent and Toddler Group is a small friendly group that runs on Fridays during term time from 9:30am till 11:15am.
Entrance is £1 per parent/child with 50p extra per child. Juice and biscuits are provided for the little ones and adults can buy tea/coffee and biscuits for 30p. No booking required, all welcome.
A small craft activity is provided together with lots of toys, role play activities and play dough. We also have a dedicated baby area with soft mats and appropriately aged toys. The group finishes with singing and instruments.
We are located in St. Michael’s Church Hall, Colehill, BH21 7AB. The building is secure, we keep the door locked – so ring the doorbell and we will welcome you in.
The group is organised by the church and run by local parents.

After graduating with an honours degree in Economics and Regional Development, Andy started his career working for a large magazine publisher before moving to work for one of the world’s largest trade show owners, project managing a portfolio of manufacturing technology trade shows across Asia.
Gaining a second degree, this time in marketing, he took on broader responsibilities within the business, particularly related to data management and marketing, as a member of the Board.
After almost 30 years in London, Andy, his wife and family, moved to Dorset in 2015 and was in May 2024 elected as a Dorset Councillor for Colehill and Wimborne Minster East.
Andy served five years as a Parent Governor at Hayeswood First School, latterly as Chair of Governors. He continues to support his school aged children.
Andy has a desire to contribute further to the community in which we live. He writes: “We are not just a “dormitory” serving Bournemouth and beyond, this is our home, and I look forward to helping the Parish Council identify and develop those things that bring us together as a community and enrich our lives.”
Andy lives and represents residents in the Colehill Parish Ward although is of course keen to hear from all and any residents in any part of Colehill.

Emerging from a small hamlet, where little had changed since medieval times, Colehill saw significant expansion in the Victorian era. Largely due to the arrival of the railway, Wimborne became prosperous and the rich of South East Dorset sought to make their homes on large estates on the slopes of Colehill.
So began the development of the village as a community. Notably, the Village School in Middlehill was founded in 1865. Ten years earlier a Primitive Methodist Chapel had been built (replaced in 1913 by the Methodist Church in Lonnen Road). The Anglican Church started as a “Tin Tabernacle” in 1881 and was in use temporarily until St Michael’s and All Angels was built in 1893. The Parish Council was formed in 1896, and met in Glyn’s Coffee Tavern in Colehill Lane.
As part of Colehill Parish Council’s centenary celebrations a commemorative booklet was produced called “100 Years of the Civil Parish of Colehill 1896-1996”. (Pages 1-6) – (pages 7-12).

Home Watch Information
Wimborne & Colehill Home Watch was formed in 2002 with the merger of all the watch groups in the area, which had developed since the first group ‘Ashmeads’ started on 28th January 1987. Today we have a membership of nearly 1100 households in Wimborne (except Merley), Colehill, Furzehill, and the part of Stapehill (down to the A31) that became ‘Colehill Hayes Ward’ on 7th May 2015.
TO JOIN please see Calling New Members! below.
Police contact details are given at the bottom of this page. Also see the Police page for Colehill Police news.

Meetings are held on the second Wednesday of every month at 7.30pm at Colehill Village Hall, Cannon Hill Road (formerly called Colehill Memorial Hall). We welcome visitors at any of our meetings.
We have a membership of 46 at present and have a mix of ages. Our meetings are lively, friendly and usually involve interesting speakers on a wide range of topics. There is always time for a cup of coffee or tea and a chat during the evening.
The ideals of the WI are as strong and important now in the 21st century as they were at the start in 1915. The WI exists to educate women, enabling them to provide an effective role in the community, to expand their horizons and to develop and pass on important skills.
We do a variety of activities outside our monthly meetings, these include walking and sewing groups. We also hope shortly to be starting an art group.
Our next meetings are as follows:
8 January – Kurling Evening
12 February – Beetles and Bingo!
12 March – The Prince’s Murderous Mistress – Steve Herra
Visitors are welcome, if you would like to contact us beforehand drop us an email.
We are a friendly group and our meetings are fun and filled with laughter.
For further information please contact us at ColehillEveningWI@dorsetWI.org or telephone Maggie Jennings on 01202 885512
Apologies if you have emailed us and we have not responded, but it has come to light that there is a problem with the Dorset WI email at the hosts end and we haven’t been receiving any emails certainly since the end of November. In the meantime until the problem is rectified please contact us on our old email address of colehillwi@gmail.com

Accessibility statement for Colehill Parish Council’s Website
This statement covers our website at https://colehill.gov.uk/.
This website is run by Colehill Parish Council.
We want as many people as possible to be able to use this website. In 2020 we substantially revised the website to realise this goal.
That means you should now be able to:
- Change colours, contrast levels and fonts (we provide basic tools for you to do this)
- Zoom in up to 250% without the text spilling off the screen
- Navigate most of the website using just a keyboard
- Navigate most of the website using speech recognition software
- Listen to most of the website using a screen reader. We have tested this with NVDA.
- We’ve also made the website text as simple as possible to understand.
AbilityNet has advice on making your device easier to use if you have a disability.
How accessible this website is
We know some parts of this website are not fully accessible:
- Older PDF documents may not be fully accessible to screen reader software
- “News” articles older than August 2019
- Old Home Watch messages from years ago
- Old Colehill Library event reports from years ago
What to do if you cannot access parts of this website
If you need information on this website in a different format like accessible PDF, large print, easy read, audio recording or braille:
Email the clerk at:
clerk@colehill.gov.uk
We’ll consider your request and do our best to help. We aim to get back to you in 10 working days, unless the Clerk is on annual leave whereby it will be looked at on her return, when the 10 working days will start.
We’re always looking to improve the accessibility of this website. If you find any problems not listed on this page or think we’re not meeting accessibility requirements, contact us the clerk at:
Email: clerk@colehill.gov.uk
Phone: 01202 880049 or 07857 597502 (8:30am – 12:30pm Monday-Friday)
Address:
Colehill Parish Council
17 Four Wells Road
Colehill
Dorset
BH21 7BA
The Equality and Human Rights Commission (EHRC) is responsible for enforcing the Public Sector Bodies (Websites and Mobile Applications) (No. 2) Accessibility Regulations 2018 (the ‘accessibility regulations’). If you’re not happy with how we respond to your complaint, contact the Equality Advisory and Support Service (EASS).
Technical information about this website’s accessibility
Colehill Parish Council is committed to making its website accessible, in accordance with the Public Sector Bodies (Websites and Mobile Applications) (No. 2) Accessibility Regulations 2018.
Compliance status
We have tested all our page templates using the aXe tool recommended by the GDS (Government Digital Service).
This website is partially compliant with the Web Content Accessibility Guidelines version 2.1 AA standard.
Non accessible content and non compliance with the accessibility regulations
The content listed below is non-accessible for the following reasons.
- PDF’s, Word, Excel, CSV, PowerPoint documents within the Publications section of the website may not be accessible.
- Any videos may not have captions
- Local events may be promoted with posters/images which aren’t accessible
- Some parts of this site link to or use content provided by other websites and these are not always as accessible as our site.
- 3rd party content which is under the control of someone else
- AGAR forms – we are not obliged to make documents accessible that we do not create and the AGAR is not our document and therefore exempt. Information from the document(s) is available during the period of public rights by contacting the Clerk.
Preparation of this accessibility statement
This website is tested for accessibility on an ongoing quarterly basis by our website developer. We will update the website to make any necessary changes as soon as possible after the need is identified.
This statement was last reviewed on 10th December 2024. The next review is due December 2025.

We are frustrated and disappointed to note that, in spite of multiple notifications posted on social media, posters on the fences and entrances to the park and the fact that the gates were taped up with hazard tape, person or persons unknown (alleged to have been teenagers) entered the Oliver’s Park children’s play area last night and damaged some of the fresh paintwork. The likelihood is that those teenagers and/or their friends will have younger brothers and sisters who will use that park and they are just spoiling it all for everyone as well as getting paint on their hands and/or clothes and causing extra work for our contractors who have to rub it down and recoat.
Please keep off until the work is finished!

Colehill is currently served by the following three bus services:
Number 13 Morebus
The number 13 Morebus serves Wimborne and Bournemouth via Stapehill, Ferndown, West Parley, Northbourne and Winton.
See the live timetable and map for 13 Morebus
Number 6h Yellow Bus
Sadly Yellow Buses ceased trading as of the 4th of August 2022, so the 6h Yellow Bus to Bournemouth Hospital is currently not operating.
Number 88 Community Bus
The 88 Community Bus is jointly funded by Colehill Parish Council and Wimborne Minster Town Council. It runs on Tuesdays, Thursdays and Fridays and provides a circular route linking Colehill with Wimborne, Kingston Lacy and Sturminster Marshall.
See the timetable for the 88 Community Bus

Healthy Homes Dorset is funded by Bournemouth, Christchurch and Poole Council, Dorset Council and Public Health Dorset and is delivered by Ridgewater Energy.
Energy Advice
Everyone is eligible for free energy advice. The advice line is open Monday-Friday, 9am-5pm and is staffed by a team of friendly and impartial Ridgewater Energy staff.
They can help with questions such as: Why are my bills so high? or Can I get help to pay my bills?
Call FREEPHONE 0300 003 7023 or text INSULATION followed by “YOUR NAME” to 07984 440584 and they will call you back.
Free Insulation and Heating Systems
If someone in your household meets the following criteria, Healthy Homes Dorset will install insulation, and in some cases, new heating systems completely free of charge:
- Has a cardiovascular condition
- Has a respiratory condition
- Has a mental health condition
- Has a disability
- Is aged 65 or over
- Has a child under 5 living in the property
- Is pregnant
- Is living with addiction
- Has attended hospital due to a fall
- Is a recent immigrant or asylum seeker
- Has a low income

Leslie joined the Council in June 2019. He is currently Chair the Finance and General Purposes Committee and has previously served as Vice-Chair of the Council. He is also an active member of many of our Working Groups. He is currently a Colehill & Wimborne Youth & Community Centre Trustee/Director (aka The Reef) – this term runs until 2028.
He and his wife moved to Colehill in 2016, after he took early retirement from his role as the Head of Project Management for a major UK Bank.
He graduated in Mathematics and Statistics and initially trained as an IT Analyst and a Business Analyst in the electricity industry, before moving into banking where he obtained professional accreditations in Project Management & Programme Management.
Leslie is interested in local history, and a keen member of the National Trust and English Heritage. He enjoys leisure cycling, gardening and walking with Bob, his Labradoodle, through the Cannon Hill Plantation most days. Having worked in the City of London for 35 years, he is very happy to have escaped to the country and is keen to contribute to making Colehill a great place to live.
Leslie lives and represents residents in the Colehill Parish Ward although is of course keen to hear from all and any residents in any part of Colehill.

Around 300 members of the community in Colehill gathered for the 2021 Remembrance Day parade and service at Colehill War Memorial, including representatives from the Parish Council, Army, Royal Air Force, Police, Fire Brigade, Scouts and Guides who all laid wreaths.
The Chair of the Parish Council, Cllr Emma Urquhart, read out the names of all our local residents that fell in the two World Wars and her husband, retired military bandsman Andy Urquhart, played the Last Post followed by the two minutes silence.
This year’s event had added meaning, as it returned to its normal format following the need to cancel the parade in 2020 due to the pandemic.
Lest we forget.

Last year we conducted a household survey asking you, among other things, what issues mattered the most to you and your family. 67% of respondents identified with the need to provide safe walking routes, particularly for children walking to and from school along Middlehill Road. In addition traffic related matters were the most common issues raised in your free format comments.
Based on this we have initiated discussions with Dorset Council to understand their process for installing new crossings. There are a lot of steps to go through to determine whether any particular site qualifies for a crossing, including counting the numbers of pedestrians and cars in the vicinity, and taking account of the number of accidents and the difficulty of crossing the road. If a site qualifies then it has to wait for funding to become available, which may take some time.
Your Feedback
Our thanks to the 95 people who responded to our recent request on this site for residents to let us know whether they would like us to pursue the possibility of pedestrian crossings being installed on Middlehill Road, and if so at what locations.
- 92% (87 people) said they support the idea of pedestrian crossings on Middlehill Road.
- 5% (5 people) object to any pedestrian crossings being constructed.
- 3 people gave no opinion, but raised other points.
On possible locations, people suggested the following sites:
- near St Michael’s church for the Middle school (16 people)
- near the co-op (19 people)
- near the pharmacy (17 people)
- near the library (6 people)
- near Colehill first school (15 people)
- near Cutlers for Hayeswood school (16 people)
We will use this feedback in our discussions with Dorset Council to understand the feasibility of installing crossings and to select the most appropriate sites for assessment.

We have just been notified that Dorset Council are consulting on a 20mph speed reduction initiative on various roads including a section of Burts Hill in Colehill from the junction with Giddylake to the junction with Deans Grove . The application has been submitted by Wimborne Minster Town Council and the area extended by Dorset Council, who are now wanting views from residents in Colehill.
This public survey has now closed. The responses will be considered at Council on 10th Dec 24, and agreement reached on how to respond to Dorset Council on this proposal.
This page will be updated once we hear of a decision on this matter.

Summary
Annual Parish Meeting
ANNUAL PARISH MEETING
What is an Annual Parish Meeting?
There can be, and often is, confusion between the Annual Parish Meeting and the Annual Parish Council Meeting. All Town and Parishes throughout England are required by law to hold an Annual Parish Meeting, which must take place between 1 March and the 1 June (inclusive). Meetings should not commence before 6pm.
What is the purpose of the Annual Parish Meeting?
The purpose of the meeting is to give local organisations including the Parish Council an opportunity to let local residents know what they have been doing over the past year. The meeting is also an opportunity for electors to have a say on anything they consider valuable to the people of the Parish.
What else happens at the meeting?
The meeting can also be an opportunity for local groups, clubs, societies and other voluntary and statutory organisations to provide an exhibition and/or have representatives from the group address those present at the meeting about the work they do and what they are involved in.
Who can attend the meeting?
The Annual Parish Meeting is for all electors of the Parish. It is not a meeting of the Parish Council. Anyone is welcome to attend the meeting however, only registered electors of the parish may speak and vote during the meeting.
Who will chair the meeting?
If the Chair of the Council is in attendance then they are legally entitled to chair the meeting. The Colehill Annual Parish Meeting is usually convened by the Chair of the Council however, the meeting could also be convened by any two Parish Councillors, a Councillor representing the Parish on the District Council, or any six local electors of the Parish.
Will I be able to ask questions and make suggestions?
Any registered elector may ask a question of the Council which will usually be answered by the Chair, the Clerk or the Council, or a designated Councillor. An elector may also make a suggestion and comment on anything pertinent to the residents of the Parish. This will be welcomed and is the whole purpose of the meeting.
Will Parish Councillors be at the meeting?
All Parish Councillors will be invited to attend and Councillors will also have an opportunity to raise questions and make comments if they wish. However, the purpose of the meeting is to enable the electors to find out what is going on in their parish and to have their say.
Will minutes of the meeting be taken?
Minutes of the proceedings of the Annual Parish Meeting shall be drawn up and entered in a book provided for the purpose. The minutes shall be reviewed and signed at the next Annual Parish Meeting.
How long will the meeting last?
The length of the meeting is dependent on the number of electors present, the number of questions asked and the discussion that is raised. Generally, the meeting will not last longer than two hours.
Where can I get copies of papers for the meeting?
The agenda calling the meeting is published 7 clear days before the meeting. The agendas and any accompanying documents will be available to download from the website on the Agendas page or by contacting the Parish Clerk on clerk@colehill.gov.uk or 01202 880049.

New donation form now available – see ‘Support Us’ below.
‘The Barbara Gooch Memorial Garden’ Appeal
We are delighted to report that the Appeal raised over £1,200. Thank you to everyone who contributed. ‘The Barbara Gooch Memorial Garden’ is located at the side of the library. Barbara was in charge of gardening volunteers and it was her dream to install a garden in this location, with plants and shrubs appropriate to the location. She and a plant expert planned the garden, but sadly, Barbara passed away before her dream could be realised.
Support Us
Our Community Library is reliant on support from the community. Here are a few ways you can help:
- Make a one-off or regular donation via the CCL Donation Form (pdf).
- Come along to a fundraising event – see our Activities & Events page
- Make a Supporter’s Subscription, via the Supporter’s Subscription form
- Help run the library and volunteer! Volunteer application form pdf (or Volunteer application form doc if you wish to fill it in using Office)
It is by volunteer effort and fund raising that we keep this community hub going. We welcome your support via small subscriptions and encourage you to join in the fundraising events. Please note that as Colehill Community Library is a registered charity we can claim Gift Aid, so it will be appreciated if you can complete the declaration where appropriate. The regular Newsletter will be sent to you by email or will be available in the library for you to collect. Also it can be downloaded from the News page.
Volunteering
We are run entirely by a substantial and committed team of volunteers who support the Library in a variety of ways. Approximately 40 volunteers man the library during opening hours over the course of a fortnight. Others are involved with general maintenance and cleaning of the building, gardening and ground maintenance, fund raising, running monthly activities and managing the Jigsaw Library.
Reg. Charity No. 1151552. Registered as a Company Limited by Guarantee 08124849.

OUR FREE TREE GIVEAWAY WAS ON SATURDAY 25th NOV 2023
Colehill Parish Council again offered free trees to Colehill residents this year as part of our action plan for the Climate Emergency.
Residents were able to collect a tree from The Reef from 1:30pm to 4pm on Saturday 25th November as part of our joint community event with Colehill Community Library who held a book sale at the same time.
The trees provided were cell-grown saplings, ranging from approximately 15cm-60cm in height, so are easy to carry away by hand. Numbers of each variety are limited and will be given out on a first come first served basis. Unfortunately for trees this size it’s possible that 10% might not grow but if your tree was unsuccessful this time and your tree didn’t grow, don’t worry we plan to offer more trees in future years.
For help with planting and caring for your tree, see the guidance from the Woodland Trust on How to Plant a Tree
Tree Varieties
Subject to availability you could choose from the varieties of tree shown below, click on each tree name for further details.
Silver birch is a popular garden tree. Tolerant of a range of temperatures, it thrives in dry woodlands, downs and heaths.
Beautiful blossom and a bounty of bright red fruits. Wild cherry , one of the prettiest native trees, is relished by gardeners and wildlife.
Rowan (Sorbus aucuparia)
Rowan grows well in light acidic soils, reaching an average height of 15m. Twigs are slender and purple-grey with purple hairy buds. Bark is greyish silver with dark horizontal markings. Clusters of white flowers appear in late spring with orange-scarlet berries in autumn. Leaves have 15 serrated leaflets arranged in pairs with a single leaf at the tip.
Hawthorn Trees & Hedges (Crataegus monogyna)
Hawthorn is an amazing tree for wildlife gardens and can be planted as a hedge or single tree. It has beautiful pink-white blossom in May and ruby-red berries, called haws, in summer. The appearance of the May blossom was the herald of the end of winter and the beginning of summer.
Hazel Trees & Hedges (Crataegus monogyna)
In spring, hazel is laden with pretty ‘lambs tail’ catkins and in autumn it produces nuts popular with wildlife. This tree responds well to close pruning. Hazel is also distinguished in legend as a magical tree that provides protection.
Dogwood Trees & Shrubs (Cornus sanguinea)
Grow this plant for its shimmering crimson and orange winter stems. In spring it has creamy white flowers and in autumn its leaves turn red. Dogwoods generally grow well (and look great) in front of an evergreen hedge where nutrients, water and sunlight are in short supply for other species.
Frequently Asked Questions
Here are some frequently asked questions about our free tree scheme…
Q: How big are the tree saplings?
A: The trees being provided are cell-grown saplings, ranging from approximately 15cm-60cm in height, depending on variety, so easy to carry away by hand.
Q: Is winter the best time to plant a tree?
A: Yes, the Woodland Trust say the best time to plant tree saplings is during winter as the trees need to be dormant when planting into new soil.
Q: I will be at work during the collection times, can someone else collect a tree on my behalf?
A: Yes you can nominate a friend, neighbour or family member to collect your tree on your behalf.
Q: Can I choose my tree species?
A: Yes, we have 6 types of tree available, as listed above, and you can pick which one you want, subject to availability.
Q: Why did Colehill Parish Council provide free trees?
A: This is one of our actions to help tackle the climate emergency. Trees are one of the best options available to offset CO2, the trees we’re giving away will when mature offset approximately 15 tonnes of CO2 per year, equivalent to the emissions from a car driving c. 70,000 miles.
Q: How can we afford to give the trees away?
A: The trees are heavily subsidised by the Woodland Trust and their sponsors.
Q: Who are the Woodland Trust?
A: The Woodland Trust are the UK’s largest Woodland Conservation Charity. They have planted 43 million trees since 1972, and aim to plant 10 million more trees every year for the next 5 years.

The Cost of Living Crisis
The UK is currently experiencing a ‘cost of living’ crisis, driven by many factors including Brexit, Covid and the war in Ukraine. Energy prices have more than doubled over the last year and are expected to continue to rise significantly in 2023, and the inflation rate is the highest seen since the early 1980s, affecting the affordablity of most goods and services.
Our Response
Colehill Parish Council has established a ‘Resilience Working Group‘ to look at what support we may be able to provide to help our residents through this crisis, with particular focus on energy bills in the upcoming Autumn/Winter of 2022/23. Updates and advice will be posted to this page as soon as they are available.
Help and Support Available
If you are concerned about the Cost of Living, see the Government’s Help for Households website for details of the help and support available to you.
Many other organisations have also established websites to help:
- Age UK – free and confidential support for older people, their families and careers, including information on housing, money, benefits, health and loneliness. Contact the local Age UK team on 01202 530530.
- Citizens Advice – see their website to check what help or benefits you may be entitled to, or contact them on 0800 144 8848 to speak to an advisor or book an appointment.
- Concerned about your energy bills? – If you think you may have difficulty in paying your energy bill, then see the Ofgem web site for advice and information on grants and benefits that might be available to help you.
- Dorset Council Help and Advice – a page providing useful advice and support on a wide range of topics including: money, food, housing, support for children, mental health, energy and employment.
- Energy Price Cap Calculator – use Martin Lewis’ online calculator to work out what you’ll pay for your energy under the new energy price cap.
- Extra Money for Older People – if you are of State Pension age with savings less than £10,000, then apply by 30th Sept for free shopping vouchers from the Household Support Fund.
- Healthy Homes Dorset – See details of Energy Advice available to all, and FREE insulation for households that qualify.
- Money Saving Expert – 90 ways to save money during this cost of living crisis.
- Turn 2 Us – check the benefits that you may be entitled to
- Which? the consumer association – Tips for energy saving and money saving.
- Pension Credit – all the information including the page to apply for Pension Credit Pension Credit: Overview – GOV.UK (www.gov.uk)

Further to the ceremonies held in both #Colehill and #Wimborne this morning, at sunset this evening the Chairman of Colehill Council, Cllr Emma Urquhart, and the Mayor of Wimborne Minster, Cllr Shane Bartlett, held a further ceremony alongside several of the 44 Commonwealth War Graves in Wimborne Cemetery, which is jointly owned and managed by Colehill, Pamphill and Wimborne.
Once again Chris Brown, who serves as Crier to both Colehill and Wimborne, cried a poem celebrating the Victory over Japan and former military bandsman Andy Urquhart played the Last Post and Reveille. Josiah Joseph (a.k.a. Antigua Joe), representing the RAF, read the Exhortation and the Kohima Epitaph.
Sunset VJ Day Ceremony at Wimborne Cemetery
August 2020

It was early in the morning of Friday 22nd February when Councillor KD Johnson snapped this photograph of the newly renovated finger-post at the junction opposite The Horns Inn at Greenhill.
This is the latest in a rolling programme of finger-post renovation by the Parish Council. In this case the work was by Nigel Harris, who lives in the village.

Emma has served on Colehill Parish Council since 2014.
She chaired the council between 2019 and 2022 and has been Chair of the Highways, Planning & Environment Committee and Vice-chair of the Finance & General Purposes Committee.
She is currently a Colehill & Wimborne Youth & Community Centre Trustee/Director (aka The Reef) – this term runs until 2028.
Emma lives and represents residents in the Colehill Parish Ward although is of course keen to hear from all and any residents in any part of Colehill.
| Address | Via the Clerk |
| Phone | Via the Clerk 01202 880049 |
| Email Address | eurquhart@colehill.gov.uk |

The Reef, the Colehill and Wimborne Youth and Community Centre, is located at Colehill Lane, Colehill, in between St Michael’s Middle School and St Michael’s and All Angels Church.
This modern building has excellent facilities and is available for public hire for parties, events, clubs and societies. Further details on the facilities and what is available within each hall is detailed here Booking – The Reef
See The Reef’s website for further information or to make a room via the online booking system.
Alternatively you can contact The Reef by phone on 01202 062121 (the line is normally staffed Tuesday to Friday 10am to 2pm).
The Reef Youth Club meets weekly in term time
Years 6 & 7– Wednesday 6:30-8pm
Years 8 & 9 – Thursday 6:30-8pm
Entry fee £1 (unless advertised otherwise)
To sign up visit the appropriate Dorset Youth Association website page – Years 6 & 7 or Years 8 & 9
All details and information on the Youth Club is accessible here Youth Club – The Reef on the Reef websites Youth Club page.
Update – April 2023
We are delighted to announce that Colehill Parish Council has now become the sole member, in effect the owner, of the Colehill and Wimborne Youth and Community Centre, also known as The Reef.
A proposal was made with the previous trustees of The Reef towards the end of 2022 to see if we would consider taking over running the building and the associated youth club, as the previous trustees wanted to retire. The Council agreed to this, with effect from 31st March 2023, and has appointed 4 of our Councillors to act as the charity trustees and as directors to manage The Reef going forwards.
The Reef is a modern building, with great facilities, and provides us with many exciting opportunities to improve the range of youth activities for Colehill, Wimborne and the surrounding area, as well as providing additional services and facilities for our wider community. We anticipate this acquisition will be highly beneficial in the years to come.

Public attendance at Council Meetings
Members of the public are warmly invited and welcome to attend Council meetings.
Council meetings are open to the public and you can stay for as long as you want. There will be places for members of the public to sit in the meeting room.
A copy of the agenda and meeting items will be available for all our meetings below.
The law does not allow members of the public to attend for items on the agenda which are confidential such as staffing. When an item of this nature comes up on the agenda the public will be asked to leave.
Speaking at a Council Meeting
Whilst we not legally obliged to allow the public to speak at a Council meeting, as part of our community engagement, we will always allow our residents to make their representations.
If you would like to ask a question or make a comment at a Council meeting and would like an immediate response please email clerk@colehill.gov.uk or call 01202 880049 at least 2 working days before the meeting.
Please when you arrive indicate to either the Chair, Clerk or any Councillor that you would like to speak and you will be permitted to do so during the Public Participation section of the meeting.
Councillors may need time to consider your questions and prepare a reply. Certain types of questions will not be answered – for example they will not answer any questions about personal circumstances.
For more information about attending council meetings see the GOV.UK guidance on attending and reporting meeting of local government.

KD Johnson was born in 1961, he is married and has two daughters, who both attended local schools. He graduated in Modern Languages from London University in 1984 and now works as a self-employed IT consultant, computer reseller and business network specialist.
He has lived in Colehill since 1988, joined the Parish Council in 1999 and was Chair of Council from 2009-2011. He is currently Vice-Chair of the Council. Between 2015 and 2019 KD represented Colehill East on the former East Dorset District Council. He serves on both standing committees of the Parish Council. He organises the regular Conservation Workdays in the woodlands owned by the Council.
KD represents Colehill on the Dorset Association of Parish and Town Councils’ (DAPTC) “Towns and Larger Parishes Committee” and also the Eastern Area Committee. As chair of the Towns and Larger Parishes Committee he is also a member of the DAPTC Executive Committee and in December 2023 he was elected as chair of DAPTC.
KD’s interests other than computers, family and The Council include amateur dramatics, wildlife and heritage conservation, country walking, archaeology and bird-watching.
KD lives and represents residents in the Colehill Parish Ward although is of course keen to hear from all and any residents in any part of Colehill.

The government introduced the Household Support Fund to provide support with rising living costs.
Dorset Council are working in partnership with Citizens Advice to administer the fund in our area.
If you are of State Pension age, resident in the Dorset Council area and have savings of less than £10,000 then you may be eligible to claim free shopping vouchers.
Apply by 30th September either online at www.dorsetcouncil.gov.uk/household-support-fund
or contact Citizens Advice on 0800 144 8848 to get help to complete an application.
See our Cost of Living page for further help, advice and money saving tips.

September 2021
Long-serving former councillor, Tony Holloway, has died at the age of 90

Dorset Council announced on 1st August the launch of a new Beryl bike hire scheme for Southeast Dorset, see their press release here. The scheme will provide 122 bikes at sites across Colehill, Wimborne, Ferndown, West Parley and West Moors. Five bays have been marked-up initially within Colehill and the first bikes will appear in those bays within the next few days.
The scheme launches just ahead of national ‘cycle to work day’ on Thursday 4th August, and it is hoped it will enable residents to reduce their car usage, helping to improve the environment and reduce road congestion.
Further details can be found on the Beryl bike website including a map showing the bay locations, pricing arrangements, and contact details for any queries.

To allay any concerns about any wholesale loss of trees in the grounds of the District Council offices there are only two due to be felled this week:
The large beech tree, which is south of the eastern wing of the offices, was identified with a disease called Ganoderma, a fungus that is one of the most significant root and butt rotters. The fungus is prevalent at the base of the tree and there are signs of it extended up the trunk, which increases the chance of failure at root level and higher up the tree.
In anticipation of the tree needing to be felled, a number of years ago a replacement beech was planted nearby. The canopy of the replacement tree has now grown up to the diseased tree’s canopy. It is appropriate that the younger healthy replacement is not impaired by the older diseased tree as their branches converge, with the likelihood of an imbalanced canopy developing on the young tree.
A lime tree located at the south western side of the offices, which overhangs the car park will also be removed. The lime tree has been losing leaf cover for some time with significant deadwood posing a risk.
The tree felling work is weather dependent and will be delayed if there are high winds or heavy rainfall.

A consultation on the Dorset Council Local Plan begins on 18 January and will last until 15 March.
Once adopted, the Local Plan will guide decisions on planning applications in Dorset until 2038.
The consultation is available online
For people who don’t have access to the plan online there are paper copies available for loan at libraries through their click and collect service. If people are shielding volunteers can help you pick up a paper copy of the plan for you from your local library. Find out more about support for those shielding
There are displays in windows of empty shops, libraries and Tourist Information Centres in some town centres.
There will also be a phone line that people can call to ask questions. This number will be available Monday – Friday 10am – 2pm. The dedicated phone line is 01305 252500.
A series of webinars will allow people to phone in and listen to, or view presentations about various sections of the plan. Once published, the webinars will be available to view at any time on our YouTube channel. Questions can be submitted in advance for the team to answer either as part of the webinar or afterwards. We will aim to respond to all questions asked to each webinar on our webpage no later than 2 weeks afterwards. There is also the ability for people who are not online to call in and listen to the webinar. This number is 0203 8554234
There are also bespoke surgeries for particular groups and town and parish councils available upon request – email for more details
A series of animations and podcasts have been developed to help explain The Dorset Council Local Plan. These can be found through Dorset Council’s social media channels or on the podcast platform Anchor.
Colehill Parish Council Response
Colehill Parish Council have agreed and submitted the following Response to the Local Plan consultation.
You may find it helpful to read our response before drafting your own, although we suggest you avoid copying our words verbatim, and use your own words to focus on aspects that matter most to you.

All three Parish Council Wards (Colehill East, Colehill West and Colehill Hayes) have not attracted enough candidates to trigger contested elections and therefore the council is elected unopposed.
Out of a maximum of 16 councillors we will initially have only 13 and will seek to fill the vacancies by co-option after May 2nd.
Click here for details.

Mini Household Survey
- During July & August 2021 we conducted a mini household survey to help us identify the key priority areas the Neighbourhood Plan should focus on.
- We made the survey available both online and on paper, with copies distributed to every household in Colehill.
- By the time the survey closed on 14th August, we’d received 621 responses, which equates to 20% of households.
- See a summary of the Mini Household Survey Results.
- We will use the results to help determine the priority topics to include in the Colehill Neighbourhood Plan.
Mini Business Survey
- During October 2021 we conducted a ‘Mini Business Survey’.
- This survey was open to any type of business based in Colehill or operating within Colehill, including private or public companies, home based businesses, schools, churches, charities and community groups & clubs.
- The purpose of the survey was to understand what business owners and managers like about operating in Colehill, and anything they would like to see changed to help their business thrive.
- In total only 7 responses were received. Given the high response rate from the Household Survey this seems low, however 99 people in the Household Survey said that they also either own a business in Colehill or work in Colehill so it’s possible that responses had already been received for many of our local businesses.
- Given the small number of responses no statistical analysis will be meaningful.

Work is about to start on the production of a Neighbourhood Plan for our parish.
A Neighbourhood Plan allows our community to decide on the planning policies we want for our area. Once approved it will have legal force, and will sit alongside the Dorset Council Local Plan to direct decisions on planning applications. It will lay out a vision for how we want Colehill to develop over the next 10 to 20 years to meet our local needs: it can set policies for the location and design of houses, environmental standards that must be met, and associated infrastructure that will be supported.
Although initiated by Colehill Parish Council, the Neighbourhood Plan can only be delivered with support from across the community. We will be seeking input from everyone who lives or works in Colehill to help us identify and shape the policies we need. Watch our noticeboards, website, and Facebook page for further updates on how you can help.
If you have any questions you can contact us at NeighbourhoodPlan@colehill.gov.uk
The map outlines in red the parish of Colehill, the area the Neighbourhood Plan will cover…

Summary
Grant Aid award
At last night’s Finance & General Purposes Committee meeting Councillors resolved to grant Planet Wimborne £100 towards the cost of this years Green Festival.
The Council is pleased to be able to contribute to this educational and interesting event which is growing in size every year and is no doubt attended by lots of Colehill residents.
More details are available here on the organisation and what the annual festival has to offer. Wimborne Green Festival | Planet Wimborne

Wimborne Fire Station is in Allenview Road, Wimborne. To find out more about the service and home safety please visit the website: Dorset and Wiltshire Fire and Rescue Service
Wimborne Fire Station is in Allenview Road, Wimborne. To find out more about the service and home safety please visit the website: Dorset and Wiltshire Fire and Rescue Service

SCOUT GROUP CELEBRATES
1st Colehill Scout Group are celebrating the opening of a second Beaver Scout Colony to join their thriving Scout Group which also runs two Cub Packs and two Scout Troops. A friendly Rounders Match with teams made up of Beavers from both Colonies and a splattering of Cubs and Scouts was followed by a mass investiture ceremony involving an impressive display of Group Colours and patriotic Flags. Helen Lynch, who got the new colony up and running, said ‘It’s brilliant that so many young people want to be part of Scouting’. Helen will be running programmes full of fun, adventure and challenge for both Colonies and will welcome enquiries for new members and adults wishing to join the fun in any section.

Successful Councillor Drop In afternoon - 26th March 2025
Council Chair Cllr Clare Davison and Cllr KD Johnson were at the Colehill Village Hall for a drop in this afternoon (26th March) where residents had the opportunity to come and speak about any local issues. The Council’s next drop in will take place on 9th April at The Reef Community Centre during our joint Easter Family Fun Day

Our Role in Planning
Colehill Parish Council are a ‘statutory consultee’ for planning applications. This means Dorset Council as our local planning authority must inform us of any planning applications affecting our parish and take our views into account when making decisions on those planning applications.
We will review all planning applications we receive and if we consider it appropriate we will submit comments to the Planning Officer in the same way that any individual may do via Dorset Council’s planning site.
In most cases Dorset Council no longer directly notify residents of planning applications submitted by their neighbours, and we’re also aware that the site notices issued by Dorset Council are not always displayed correctly. So to help improve transparency for our residents we have agreed to establish this page to share details of all planning applications we receive.
If you wish to provide comments or objections to Dorset on an application then please click on the link provided below against the appropriate application number. Note the public consultation period is normally 21 days.
Where consultation timescales allow we will schedule the planning application for discussion at our next appropriate meeting, normally a meeting of the Highways, Plans & the Environment Committee (HPE). You will be welcome to attend that meeting to provide your comments directly to our councillors.

Summary
Grant Aid awards
At the Council meeting on 16th April, Grant Aid was awarded to two Colehill organisations namely Colehill Community Library and Girlguiding Colehill Unit.
The Library received £13,334.64 which covers both their annual basic running costs (Electricity, Gas, Council tax/business rates, consumables etc) as well as funding for a new noticeboard which will be installed on the pavement approaching the library.
The Girl Guides at the Colehill unit were awarded £168 to fund their trip into Westminster Abbey on 21st June.
Colehill Parish Council is always thrilled to be in a position to help local organisation that do so much to enhance the lives of our residents.
Applications can be made 10 months of the year with all details on the Grant Aid section of the website.

Colehill Parish Council have been informed about a proposal to install a 18 metre tall 5G telecommunications mast, and a number of associated cabinets, on the corner opposite the co-op shop, at the junction of Smugglers Lane and Wimborne Road.
See the information that has currently been provided to us for the 5G Mast Pre-Consultation.
This is at the pre-consultation stage, which means a formal planning application has not yet been submitted. The Council has been invited to provide our initial feedback, in advance of the formal planning process starting.
What is 5G?
5G is a new type of mobile internet connection, approximately 10 times faster than the existing 4G mobile network and allowing far more devices to access the internet at the same time. The mobile networks started to rollout 5G in 2019, and it is currently available in over 100 towns and cities across the UK. It is estimated as many as 400,000 masts will be required over the next few years to complete the rollout.
What Will it Look Like?
We attach an impression showing how we think the mast and supporting cabinets will appear based on the information sent to us by the telecoms company…
.
Thank You for Your Views
Our thanks to the 373 people who completed our survey to provide feedback on the pre-consultation:
- Only 17% supported a 5G mast at the proposed location.
- A clear majority, 55%, support 5G masts in Colehill but not at the proposed location.
- 24% object to any 5G masts being erected.
We will use this information, and the many helpful comments provided, to shape our response and discussions with the telecommunications company. Please watch the news pages on this web site for further updates.

At Southern Cygnet Swim School we teach swimming in a safe and happy environment whilst encouraging progress with confidence.
Southern Cygnet Swim School poster (pdf)
Pupils are placed according to ability in small classes (maximum of 6 pupils).
All lessons are run at St Michael’s Middle School.
A free trial lesson is offered to all new pupils allowing them to experience a lesson, have the chance to meet their potential swim teacher and swim helper and be introduced to the swim school environment before committing to a term of lessons.
Where appropriate swim teachers and swim helpers are in the water encouraging independence and confidence in the water.
All lessons are personal and unpressured, allowing the children to progress at their own pace and so develop into confident and happy swimmers.
There is always a responsible adult or lifeguard supervising the lessons, giving you the parent, peace of mind that your child is safe at all times.
As well as running swimming lessons for children from the age of 3, we also offer Rookie Lifeguard sessions and Teen Swim Fit sessions and Adult Swimming Lessons.
Rookie Lifeguard is primarily aimed at swimmers who are 8-12 years old and are able to swim at least 25 metres.
The Rookies learn how to take care of themselves, their family and friends in and around the water. They work towards awards which require a thorough understanding of survival, rescue and sports skills as well as life support and water safety elements.
Teen Swim Fitness is for swimmers who have reached a good standard of swimming but no longer wish to attend structured lessons but would like to keep their fitness at a good level.
This session runs for 1 hour on a Wednesday 5.30pm – 6.30pm where the swimmers follow set programmes to build their stamina and fitness whilst the instructor keeps an eye on their technique and gives tips to improve efficiency.
This session also compliments swimmers who are still attending lessons if they would like to swim more than once a week.
Adult Swimming Lessons
Adult lessons are for any level of swimmer, and all our current adult swimmers have made a huge amount of progress this term. Being able to swim confidently is life changing.
For our beginners, the smile on their faces, and sense of achievement when they manage their first length unaided, is something a teacher won’t forget, and is a feeling the swimmers will remember for a long time to come.
For our intermediate and advanced swimmers – getting that step closer to achieving their goal of swimming an open water events or learning a new stroke with correct aquatic breathing is hugely satisfying
Aqua Exercise
It’s not just your heart and muscles that benefit from an aquafit class; it’s also fantastic for your internal organs and lymphatic system. Working out in water reduces impact and stress on joints and strain on the heart. It is also beneficial whilst recovering from injury and illness. Exercising in water is easier than on land and from the start one is able to exercise for longer and more strenuously while staying cool.
And if you’re COOL, it’s FUN!
All of these benefits contribute to the “feel good factor” and our classes are suitable for men and women of all shapes, sizes, and any fitness level, promoting a wonderful sense of wellbeing.
Remember the more you push yourself the better the results will be!
Come along on a Monday 7.00pm – 7.45pm or on a Wednesday 2.00pm – 2.45pm and have a go.
First session free then £5.50 per session. What have you got to lose?
Parking for the Wednesday daytime session is outside of the school gates on the road.
If you or your children fit into any of these categories above, do think about taking the plunge as we can get you that step closer to achieving your goal no matter how great or small!
For further information or to book a space please contact Amelia on:
07951 214296
